articles.headline: Agency’s Head Expects Banking’s Crisis to Worsen
articles.snippet: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned that the nation’s ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further and raised the number of “problem” lenders.
articles.abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned that the nation’s ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further and raised the number of “problem” lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Sheila C. Bair anticipated the mortgage crisis long before most other regulators. But she never dreamed it would wreak so much havoc on so many banks.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: China’s Promise Excites the Sports Stars
articles.snippet: The Olympics’ star athletes are hoping to cash in on Chinas’s boom in sports marketing and sponsorship deals.
articles.abstract: The Olympics’ star athletes are hoping to cash in on Chinas’s boom in sports marketing and sponsorship deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  At times during the Olympics, athletes like Dwyane Wade and Serena Williams seemed to be working as hard off the court as on they were on the court.

articles.headline: Wind Energy Bumps Into Power Grid’s Limits
articles.snippet: Clean energy’s dirty secret is that while generating it is getting easier, moving it to market is not.
articles.abstract: Clean energy’s dirty secret is that while generating it is getting easier, moving it to market is not.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the builders of the Maple Ridge Wind farm spent $320 million to put nearly 200 wind turbines in upstate New York, the idea was to get paid for producing electricity. But at times, regional electric lines have been so congested that Maple Ridge has been forced to shut down even with a brisk wind blowing.

articles.headline: Taliban Gain New Foothold in Afghan City
articles.snippet: A June jailbreak highlighted the Afghan government’s frailty, and the security situation has worsened since.
articles.abstract: A June jailbreak highlighted the Afghan government’s frailty, and the security situation has worsened since.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban bomber calmly parked a white fuel tanker near the prison gates of this city one evening in June, then jumped down from the cab and let out a laugh. Prison guards fired on the bomber as he ran off, but they missed, instead killing the son of a local shopkeeper, Muhammad Daoud, who watched the scene unfold from across the street.

articles.headline: Cities Debate Privatizing Public Infrastructure
articles.snippet: Governments are overcoming their wariness of private funds as they struggle to finance public improvements.
articles.abstract: Governments are overcoming their wariness of private funds as they struggle to finance public improvements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cleaning up road kill and maintaining runways may not sound like cutting-edge investments. But banks and funds with big money seem to think so.

articles.headline: On a National Stage, Paterson Takes an Aggressive Approach
articles.snippet: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York and his aides considered his short speech at the Democratic National Convention an important appearance as he tries to raise his national profile.
articles.abstract: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York and his aides considered his short speech at the Democratic National Convention an important appearance as he tries to raise his national profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  Gov. David A. Paterson arrived here for the Democratic National Convention this week with an extra bounce in his step, emboldened by his success in getting the Legislature to heed his call to cut hundreds of millions of dollars out of the state budget.

articles.headline: Clinton Rallies Her Troops to Fight for Obama
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made a soaring appeal to support Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made a soaring appeal to support Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER  With her husband looking on tenderly and her supporters watching with tears in their eyes, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton deferred her own dreams on Tuesday night and delivered an emphatic plea at the Democratic National Convention to unite behind her rival, Senator Barack Obama, no matter what ill will lingered.
